item.question: I am using Internet Explorer 6 (or earlier, < 7.0), why does your site look like crap?
item.faqanswer: Let's face it, Internet Explorer 6 is probably one of, if not the crappiest of browsers available. The Trident render engine included in IE 6 and earlier is not even up to par with web standards, and so it makes PNG images look bad, with a light blue background (unless I hack it, which I won't do), and it doesn't agree with all of the CSS 2 -- it doesn't support Web Standards! If you are using IE 6 on Windows XP, then please upgrade to IE 7, because Microsoft stopped supporting that on 10 October 2006, but if you're using it on Windows 2000, then it's supposed to be supported until 2010 (sadly you can't upgrade to IE 7 on Windows 2000, however). If you cannot upgrade your browser, then use a third party browser that supports web standards, such as Firefox, Safari, or Chrome. If you are using a Macintosh and using IE 5 or earlier, then definitely upgrade, because Microsoft doesn't support that at all anymore, and why should they?

item.question: What technologies did you use to create this website?
item.faqanswer: I focus most of my work on XHTML, XML, CSS, and JavaScript. These are all web standards (see W3C and The Web Standards Project. For my back end I typically utilize PHP or ASP.NET. This website was written in PHP. My goal is to write as much as possible in pure client-side languages, but when security and validation play a role, I utilize back-end technologies such as PHP and ASP.NET. I also am able to produce websites using CGI scripts written in Perl and other scripting languages, though I did not do that here.
